Red Hot Organization Archive
Red Hot Organization
Carlin, John, 1955-
MSS.191
40.25 Linear Feet
1989-2004 The Red Hot Organization is an international organization dedicated to fighting AIDS through pop culture. First founded as King Cole, Inc. by Leigh Blake and John Carlin in 1989, Red Hot Organization has since produced fourteen albums, related television programs and media events incorporating the talents of performers, visual artists, producers and directors to raise funds and awareness for HIV and AIDS. The collection contains the production files of the organization's projects, including administrative records and financial files, and merchandise such as CDs, videos, and t-shirts. The collection also contains raw and finished film, video, and audio media, which is currently unprocessed and not available for research use.
Historical Note
The Red Hot Organization is an international organization dedicated to fighting AIDS through pop culture. First founded as King Cole, Inc. by Leigh Blake and John Carlin in 1989, Red Hot Organization has since produced fourteen albums, related television programs and media events incorporating the talents of performers, visual artists, producers and directors to raise funds and awareness for HIV and AIDS.
To date, Red Hot's efforts have donated nearly 7 million dollars for AIDS relief around the world. Besides funding AIDS research and education, Red Hot awarded grants in cooperation with existing AIDS organizations, such as the National Minority AIDS Council. Revenues from the sale of albums and videos in foreign countries remained within each respective country to help support local AIDS prevention and relief.
(Reference: www.redhot.org)
Scope and Content
The Red Hot Organization Archive contains the production files of the organization's projects, including administrative records and financial files, and merchandise such as CDs, videos, and t-shirts. The collection also contains raw and finished film, video, and audio media, which is currently unprocessed and not available for research use. CDs and other media found in Merchandise series may be accessible upon request.
Numerous oversize items found at the end of each of the series include t-shirts, posters, and other oversize promotional material housed in boxes.
Arrangement
Red Hot Organization Collection is generally organized into series by Red Hot Organization projects undertaken between 1990 and 2005. The series are arranged chronologically according to each project's release date.
Materials within series are arranged alphabetically, with all efforts made to preserve the original titles and classifications of the collection.

Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Red Hot Organization Archive; MSS 191; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.
Use Restrictions
Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.
Provenance
The Red Hot Organization Archive was donated to the Fales Library by Red Hot's founder, John Carlin, in 2006.
Access Restrictions
Repository permission is required for access. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Audiovisual and born-digital materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.

Series I: Red Hot + Blue
Scope and Contents
Red Hot + Blue was released in 1990 and was the first in the Red Hot series. Red Hot + Blue featured contemporary pop performers reinterpreting the songs of Cole Porter. An accompanying television special featured videos for all but two songs.
In 2006 Red Hot + Blue was re-issued on a special two-disc set including the original CD remastered, and a DVD of the home video.

Scope and Contents
Red Hot + Dance was released in 1992 by Columbia Records, featuring three exclusive tracks from George Michael. Other major dance artists donated tracks, remixed by D.J.s and producers from around the world. An accompanying home video was released by Sony Music Video Enterprises. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)
An anomaly exists in Series II: Red Hot + Dance. An additional series, designated as Subseries L, pertains to the legal dispute between George Michael and Sony Music. Scope and Contents
Red Hot + Country was released in 1994 by Mercury Nashville, featuring classic country and rock songs performed by old and new country artists. The album received two Grammy nominations. An accompanying home video was released by PolyGram Video. Stolen Moments: Red Hot + Cool was released by GRP Records in 1994, featuring collaborations between jazz performers and hip hop artists. A documentary film focusing on the impact of AIDS on communities of color was broadcast on PBS in tandem with the album release, and released on home video by PolyGram Video. Audio compact discRed Hot + Bothered CD insert (back)cuid76411995865Series VIII: The Beat Experience / Offbeat: A Red Hot Soundtrip
General
This series encompasses both "The Beat Experience" CD-ROM/Video and "Offbeat: A Red Hot Soundtrip" enhanced audio CD.
Released by WAX TRAX / TVT in 1996, "Offbeat: A Red Hot Soundtrip" was an offshoot of The Beat Experience, a project exploring the legacy of the Beat generation produced by The Red Hot Organization in association with the Whitney Museum of American Art. "The Beat Experience" CD-ROM combines text, jazz, underground films and visual art to anthologize the period, while "The Beat Experience" video is an hour TV show that presents the era in a contemporary edit of archive filmclips, sound bites, music and abstract imagery.

Scope and Content
Onda Sonora: Red Hot + Lisbon was released in 1998 by Bar/None in North America, Movieplay Portuguesa in Europe, and Trama in Brasil. The album features 40 artists from 11 countries singing in 7 languages, and was created in conjunction with the 1998 World Expo in Lisbon Portugal. Audio sound discSeries XV: Optic Nerve: David Wojnarowicz on CD-ROM
Scope and Content
Optic Nerve: David Wojnarowicz on CD-ROM was released by Red Hot Organization in 1999. Optic Nerve was produced by Red Hot Organization and Funny Garbage in conjunction with the New Museum of Contemporary Art's exhibit, Fever: The Art of David Wojnarowicz. The CD-ROM encompasses music, writing, film, painting and performance by Wojnarowicz.
Optic Nerve was originally available from the New Museum bookstore in New York City. $4 per unit from the sale of each disc was donated to the Hetrick Martin Institute, which Wojnarowicz supported during his lifetime.

Scope and Content
What's Going On was released in 2001 by Sony in collaboration with Artists Against AIDS Worldwide (AAAW), featuring remakes of Marvin Gaye's "What's Going On." AAAW was founded by Leigh Blake, co-founder of Red Hot Organization.
